thread.title: Kansas falls short in upset bid of Texas Tech despite rejuvenated passing game
thread.title_full: Kansas falls short in upset bid of Texas Tech despite rejuvenated passing game

author: Jesse Newell
title: Kansas falls short in upset bid of Texas Tech despite rejuvenated passing game
text:
Kansas falls short in upset bid of Texas Tech despite rejuvenated passing game True freshman QB, defense productive in 30-20 defeat Posted: October 17, 2015 - 4:05pm Back | Next THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Kansas wide receiver Darious Crawley reaches the ball across the goal line for a touchdown as he is defended by Texas Tech defensive back J.J. Gaines, middle right, and defensive lineman Branden Jackson, left, during the second half Saturday's game at Memorial Stadium in Lawrence. Texas Tech won 30-20. Back | Next THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Kansas freshman quarterback Ryan Willis (13) completed 35 of 50 passes for 350 yards, the highest output by a KU quarterback since Todd Reesing in 2009, but the Jayhawks' upset bid against Texas Tech still fell short, 30-20, Saturday in Lawrence. By Jesse Newell jesse.newell@cjonline.com 
LAWRENCE — Ryan Willis led Kansas to the brink of a major upset, but he couldn’t quite finish the feat. 
The true freshman threw a pick-six with 4:07 left in the game, ending KU’s hopes of victory in a 30-20 loss to Texas Tech on Saturday at Memorial Stadium. 
What happened before that, though, was one of KU’s most encouraging signs this season. The Miege product completed 35 of 50 passes for 350 yards, which was the highest output by a KU quarterback since Todd Reesing in 2009. 
KU’s defense also played its best game. Texas Tech, which allowed just two sacks in its first six games, surrendered five to KU on Saturday, as the Jayhawks’ defensive line hurried QB Patrick Mahomes most of the day. The Red Raiders’ 30 points also were a season low. 
KU, which entered as a 33-point underdog, trailed 20-0 at half before starting its comeback. The Jayhawks scored three second-half TDs, capped by a Taylor Cox 1-yard run with 6:26 left in the fourth that cut the lead to 23-20. 
The Jayhawks’ defense forced a punt on the ensuing possession, but Willis followed with his only interception. 
KU (0-6, 0-3 Big 12) also had better success in the run game, with De’Andre Mann posting 107 yards on 15 carries. 
Mahomes was 30-for-51 for 359 yards with a touchdown and interception for Tech (4-2, 1-2). 
KU will play at Oklahoma State at 2:30 p.m. on Oct. 24. 
Texas Tech (5-3, 2-2) 3 17 3 7 — 30 
Kansas (0-6, 0-3) 0 0 6 14 — 20 
FIRST QUARTER 
TTU — Hatfield 30 field goal, 0:36. Drive: 12 plays, 77 yards, 3:35 time of possession. 
SECOND QUARTER 
TTU — Washington 1 run (Clark rush), 13:10. Drive: 6-61, 1:27. 
TTU — Hatfield 24 field goal, 10:13. Drive: 5-50, 1:25. 
TTU — Davis 45 pass from Mahomes (Hatfield kick blocked), 1:02. Drive: 9-80, 1:18. 
THIRD QUARTER 
KU — Crawley 10 pass from Willis (Wyman kick failed), 5:39. Drive: 11-69, 4:30. 
TTU — Hatfield 25 field goal, 1:17. Drive: 14-68, 4:22. 
FOURTH QUARTER 
KU — Parmalee 25 pass from Willis (Bartolotta kick), 10:32. Drive: 4-33, 1:32. 
KU — Cox 1 run (Bartolotta kick), 6:26. Drive: 9-55, 2:56. 
TTU — Jah. Johnson 27 interception return (Hatfield kick), 4:07. 
Attendance — 25,186.
